title: Books
text:
This is a list I’ve gathered of various books available online (and possibly download to PDF).
Really, there’s already an Awesome R Learning Resources Github repository with a similar list of books and other resources specific to R, data science, statistics, etc. Many books I have listed on this page overlap with the list from that link, but not all. Some of the links listed on that page are dead. I actually didn’t realize that Awesome R list of resources existed until…today (August 2023). So everything below are links to books I found on my own as I was struggling and hyper-fixating on the wrong things. “IF ONLY SOMEONE HAD TOLD ME, GUIDED ME” I say to myself as I perpetuate the ruthless cycle.
Many of these books are commonly known, some are better than others. I have yet to organize this list into coherent categories. Right now, there’s a mix of content here which ranges from
All of this stuff overlaps to some extent, so current organization is fickle. I haven’t read through most of these, but neither have you so whatever.

title: Welcome!
text:
Hi. I’m Isaiah. This is my website. I made it using Quarto. It’s a work in progress.



 Back to top

title: Methods
text:
An mostly unorganized list of links to resources that have helped, are helpful, or might be helpful. These are not books but instead a variety of online resources, tutorials, data banks, guides, short articles, blogs, and references for various method techniques. I have not curated this yet to be organized into different methods.



Sage Research Methods

Really useful reference for research methods. Includes guides, video tutorials, reading lists, books, references, and much more.
May require institutional access

PoliSciData

This should be more widely known as a central source for political scientists, especially to support ongoing data collection efforts. There’s a lot here and all of it useful

psyTeachR

This resource is incredible. Just check it out.
“The psyTeachR team at the University of Glasgow School of Psychology and Neuroscience has successfully made the transition to teaching reproducible research using R across all undergraduate and postgraduate levels. Our curriculum now emphasizes essential ‘data science’ graduate skills that have been overlooked in traditional approaches to teaching, including programming skills, data visualisation, data wrangling and reproducible reports. Students learn about probability and inference through data simulation as well as by working with real datasets.”
“This website contains our open materials for teaching reproducible research. See our GitHub for open data and code.”

Foundations of Inference | PoliSciData
Logistic Regression with R Tutorials | PoliSciData

Where were you when I needed you?

Growth Curve Modeling
Graphical & Latent Variable Modeling

Pretty good intro/information on Structural Equation Modeling (e.g., latent variable modeling) by Michael Clark (I don’t know him).

lavaan R package tutorial
MIXED EFFECTS LOGISTIC REGRESSION | R DATA ANALYSIS EXAMPLES

UCLA Statistical Methods and Data Analytics Data analysis example for Mixed effects logistic regression in R

INTRODUCTION TO GENERALIZED LINEAR MIXED MODELS

UCLA Statistical Methods and Data Analytics introduction to generalized linear mixed models (GLMMs)

Plotting partial pooling in mixed-effects models

A few techniques for plotting partial pooling in mixed-effects models in R, by Tristan Mahr

Fixed- and Mixed-Effects Regression Models in R

Intro to Fixed- and Mixed-effects Regression models in R by Martin Schweinberger
The University of Queensland, Australia. School of Languages and Cultures

A Beginner’s Guide to Marginal Effects

University of Virginia Library Research Data Services + Sciences beginner’s guide to marginal effects

Correlation of Fixed Effects in lme4
Getting Started with Multinomial Logit Models
Understanding Empirical Cumulative Distribution Functions
Understanding QQ Plots
Understanding Diagnostic Plots for Linear Regression Analysis
Comparing Mixed-Effect Models in R and SPSS
Getting Started with Generalized Estimating Equations
Getting Started with Binomial Generalized Linear Mixed Models
Getting Started with Web Scraping in Python
Convert Logit to Probability

Simple method on how to convert logit to probability
From Sebastian Sauer’s PhD stats blog

Mathematical Annotation in R

How to include mathematical symbols and formulas in plots created with R

Andrew Heiss PhD Blog
MLM with R and brms to work with country-year panel data
Calculate posterior predictions and average marginal effects with multilevel Bayesian models
MLM Specification using lme4 package
lmer cheat sheet|Stackexchange
lme/lmer to fit different two- and three-level longitudinal models

by Kristoffer Magnusson PhD

Mixed Models with R

A whole thing made my Michael Clark

Statistical Rethinking Recoded

Solomon Kurz essentially replicates Richard McElreath’s textbook Statistical Rethinking using brms R package and ggplot2

Reliability Analysis

Tutorial on how to conduct an analysis of reliability (i.e., internal consistency) using the alpha function from the R psych package
the alpha function reports two estimates of reliability: Cronbach’s coefficient \(\alpha\) and Guttman’s Lambda 6 \(\lambda_6\)

Exploratory Factor Analysis in R

Factor analysis is a method used to search for unobserved variables (i.e., factors) from observational data
This link only covers Exploratory Factor Analysis (EFA), not Conformatory Factor Analysis (CFA)

How, When, and Why Should you Normalize/Standardize/Rescale Your Data?

A thing I find useful
Doesn’t use R, but (appears to be) python

Rescaling

a short review on rescaling sets of variables to be on the same scale
not an R tutorial
by Chrisos Giannoulis, PhD

Centering and Standardizing Predictors

a short review on the difference between centering and standardizing
by Karen Grace-Martin

How to Construct an Index for Research | ThoughtCo

by Ashley Crossman
For of a review of concept and method, not an R tutorial
I find these helpful as a happy-medium between taking and reviewing my own piss-poor notes and diving into some textbook chapter I failed to bookmark.

Scales Used in Social Science Research | ThoughtCo

another by Ashley Crossman. This time on scales

Cluster Analysis and How Its Used in Research | ThoughtCo

by Ashley Crossman again

Principal Components and Factor Analysis | ThoughtCo

Brief Ashley Crossman article on Principal Components Analysis (PCA) and Factor Analysis (FA)

Robust Regression using R

Regression tutorial by Alastair Sanderson

title: Resources
text:
This is continuously being updated. So far it is a list of resources I have found that is either useful or potentially useful. Some of these I have used so often, others I have not ever utilized but saved anyway. I’m updating and organizing this page as you read this.



 Back to top

title: Tutorials
text:
As I figure out how to do useful things, I will add tutorials. Or, more likely, I will add links to tutorials I find useful. The one’s I have begun are nowhere near ready to be published here. Check back soon.



 Back to top

title: C.V.
text:
Here is a link to a downloadable PDF copy of my C.V



 Back to top

title: Books and Documentation related to various R Packages
text:
Books and Documentation related to various R Packages
There’s, what, gabazillions of R packages out there? Some are useful, some suck, and it takes more than a few late nights to learn how to tell the difference. Learning R and subsequently how to build your own R package is probably the best way to start from a solid foundation. But who the hell starts with a solid foundation? Not I, for one. So I’ve gathered a bunch of packages that have been useful, are consistently useful, or might be useful later, for the kind of things I do in R/RStudio/Quarto.

Tidyverse

moderndive

Officeverse
(https://www.joshuapkeller.com/page/introregression/)
(https://ggplot2-book.org/index.html)
(https://rkabacoff.github.io/datavis/)
(http://asdfree.com/)
(https://benwhalley.github.io/just-enough-r/)
(https://adv-r.hadley.nz/index.html)
(https://design.tidyverse.org/)
(https://bookdown.org/bean_jerry/using_r_for_educational_research/)
(https://jslefche.github.io/sem_book/index.html)
(https://bookdown.org/yih_huynh/Guide-to-R-Book/)
(https://stefvanbuuren.name/fimd/)
(https://geanders.github.io/RProgrammingForResearch/)
(https://bookdown.org/kieranmarray/intro_to_r_for_econometrics/)
(https://dereksonderegger.github.io/570L/)
(https://opengovdata.io/)
(https://trevorfrench.github.io/R-for-Data-Analysis/?es_id=aaa755b1d8)
(https://psyteachr.github.io/ads-v1/index.html)
(https://frederikaust.com/papaja_man/)
(https://hbiostat.org/rflow/)
(https://www.tidytextmining.com/index.html)
(https://bookdown.org/ejvanholm/WorkingWithData/)
(https://bookdown.org/ejvanholm/Textbook/)
(https://crumplab.com/programmingforpsych/index.html)
(https://bookdown.org/dli/rguide/)
(https://bookdown.org/tomholbrook12/bookdown-demo/)
(https://www.tidymodels.org/books/)
(https://socviz.co/)
(https://tutorials.quanteda.io/-





 Back to top

title: Books
section: Stats and Methods and Maths, Oh My!
text:
Stats and Methods and Maths, Oh My!


Advanced Data Science
Moderndive: Statistical Inference via Data Science

Also see Learn the tidyverse which provides links to a few more related topics.

Quantitative Research Methods for Political Science, Public Policy and Public Administration: 4th Edition With Applications in R
Lab Guide to Quantitative Research Methods in Political Science, Public Policy & Public Administration.

companion book to open-source textbook listed above

STAT 545: Data Wrangling, Exploration, and Analysis with R

This site is about everything that comes up during data analysis except for statistical modelling and inference.

The Effect: An Introduction to Research Design and Causality
Foundations of Statistics with R
R for Researchers: An Introduction
Exploratory Data Analysis with R
Telling Stories with Data With Applications in R
Learning statistics with R: A tutorial for psychology students and other beginners
Learning Statistics with R
R for Psychological Science
Mastering Shiny
The Data Preparation Journey: Finding Your Way With R

This appears to be a work in progress but there’s a lot that seems useful.

Social Science Theory

This is more of like a list of many social science theories.
